doc.field: Bundestag approves German participation in Kosovo

The parliament in Bonn approved the deployment of Bundeswehr soldiers in a NATO-led peace force in Kosovo with a large majority. 556 members voted for it, only 42 against it. There were 10 abstentions. Defense minister Scharping said the pressure on Serbs and Kosovo-Albanians must remain to avoid a humanitarian catastrophe which could lead to more refugees to Western Europe. Foreign Minister Fischer stressed that peace in Kosovo would be impossible without military guard. He also said that it is important to have an international force under NATO command. The former Defense Minister Ruehe mentioned that military action in Kosovo would take the Bundeswehr to its breaking point.

Economy and labor market politics were the focus of budget talks in the Bundestag. It was stressed that growth factors should be mobilised and mass unemployment fought. Minister of Economics Mueller justified his budget and advertised for initiatives of the private industry. Minister of Employment Riester called the 1999 budget a plan to reduce unemployment. Minister of Transportation Muentefering stressed that he would support the construction of the controversial magnetic aerial railway 'Transrapid'.
Work team to come up with further steps for tax reform

The federal government, unions and employers are planning to come up with a joint program for further steps of the enterprise and the eco tax reform. Chancellor Schroeder said the team should come up with a conclusive draft. The judgement of the Federal Constitutional Court for the betterment of families would have to be taken into consideration as well. Mr Schroeder stressed that the labor alliance would be continued, and that the next meeting is scheduled for mid May.
Ministers taking stronger measures against Kurdish rioters

The Ministers of the Interior and Justice of the states are planning to take stronger measures against Kurdish rioters. At a conference in Bonn they encouraged the Federal Government to have talks with the Turkish Government to avoid that expelled Kurds are tortured or killed in Turkey. Federal Interior Minister Otto Schily stressed that an assent in Ankara should be monitored.

Public sector unions expanded their warning strikes one day before the third round of negotiations in Stuttgart. About 100,000 employees in 150 cities stopped working for several hours, mainly in North-Rhine Westphalia, Lower Saxony, Berlin and Brandenburg, above all affecting public local transportation and garbage collection.
Baden-Wuerttemberg metal compromise finds use in NRW

The settlement for the metal industry in Baden-Wuerttemberg is supposed to be adopted by Northrine-Westphalia as well according to an agreement reached by employers and the metal union in Wuppertal. The Wage Commission of the IG Metall union and the majority of the regional employer associations have to agree first.
Bishops' views of counseling program undisclosed

The views of the Catholic church regarding the counseling program for pregnant women in conflict remains undisclosed. The result of the bishops' votes will not be disclosed in the near future, and only after consultation with Pope John Paul II. Apparently the bishops reached a compromise in which the consultation certificate will be expanded to encompass support and legal claims for the pregnant women.
France rejects German proposal for EU agricultural reform

France rejects the compromise proposal by the German council presidency for an EU agricultural reform. The French Agriculture Minister Galvany said in Brussels the plan would burden the European Union with additional 12 billion euro which needed to be charged to the agricultural budget of the individual states. The EU ministers negotiated today for the fourth day in a row, expecting to reach an agreement that can be presented before the EU summit on Friday.
32 died in avalanche in Paznaun Valley

All persons who wanted to leave the ski resort Galtuer have been evacuated. Since yesterday, approximately 3,000 persons have been brought out of the avalanche region. Today alone, about 1,800 holidaymakers and residents were evacuated by helicopter. More tourists will be evacuated tonight and tomorrow. 32 people died in the avalanche catastrophe; at least 12 of them were German. More persons are still missing.
